lines.text:
[referring to Mary Blake]
Well, there's no law against an opera singer being slender, young and beautiful.
I'm going to stay.

That's right. You're in probably the wickedest, most corrupt city, most Godless city in America. Sometimes it frightens me. I wonder what the end's going to be. But nothing can harm you if you don't allow it to because nothing in the world, no one in the world, is all bad.
Well sister, what's your racket?
I'm a singer!
Let's see your legs!
I said, I'm a singer!
[pointing at necklace]
Hey. I thought I told you not to wear that thing.
Ah gee, honey, I think it's nice.
Yeah? Well I think it makes you look cheap!
[Rips it off of her]
Now don't wear it anymore. Blackie doesn't like it.

[to a bartender]
"Everyone to his own taste," the old lady said as she kissed the cow. Ain't that a...
[not getting a reaction]
What's the matter? No sense of humor?

[referring to the earthquake]
Well, we certainly don't do things halfway in San Francisco.
One never knows where one's gonna find talent.
No, no, one never does, does one?

That process server is the meanest man west of the Rocky Mountains. He'd push his mother off a ferry boat for half a dollar. Yeah, he'd turn the air off in a baby's incubator just to watch the little sucker squirm.
Hello, Della. I'm glad to see you again.

You won't be for long. I just dropped over to tell you what I think of you. You know, I haven't seen this woman since she walked out on the best man in San Francisco to marry the town's number one rodent.
I think you better go, Della.

Oh, no. I've got a few things I want to tell you, too. Now, in case you folks don't follow me, I'll tell you that this mouse here has just had a padlock put on The Paradise and thrown all of Blackie Norton's performers in jail. That's what Blackie got for picking this phony up out of the gutter and giving her a chance.
Come on, folks.
Hold still. Don't think I want to breathe the air near you any longer than I have to. You ought to make that mouse awfully happy. Here's a five spot, brother. I'm buying back me introduction to you.
Did you ever hear of Puccini, Norton?
Yeah. Didn't he run a joint down on Dupont Street?
